title: Prototype: Help docs via online docs in browser
description:
Prototype approach for viewing SuperCollider help docs by opening online documentation in browser.

## Approach
1. Add Zed task `SuperCollider: Help` that takes selection
2. Construct URL: `https://docs.supercollider.online/Classes/${SYMBOL}`
3. Run `open "$URL"` to launch in default browser

## Pros
- Very simple, no server changes needed
- Docs are always up-to-date
- Full search, navigation, cross-references work

## Cons
- Leaves Zed (context switch)
- Requires internet
- Need to handle non-class docs (Guides, Reference, etc.)

## URL patterns
- Classes: `/Classes/SinOsc`
- Guides: `/Guides/Introduction`  
- Reference: `/Reference/Literals`
- Search: `/Search.html?query=...`

## Research findings

### Online docs
- Hosted at https://docs.supercollider.online
- Built from schelp via Docker/sclang → HTML (supercollider/sc-docs repo)
- Updated weekly from latest SC release
- Has search functionality at `/Search.html`

### Zed task integration
- Can use `ZED_SELECTED_TEXT` or `ZED_CUSTOM_*` env vars
- Existing tasks in `.zed/tasks.json` show the pattern
- `open` command on macOS opens URLs in default browser

### Why not LSP-based?
- `window/showDocument` not implemented in Zed (Discussion #24852)
- When LSP servers try to use it, Zed just shows text notification
- Users must manually copy URL - bad UX

### Fallback behavior
- If symbol not found as class, could fall back to search URL
- `/Search.html?query=SinOsc` shows search results

## Implementation sketch
```json
{
  "label": "SuperCollider: Help",
  "command": "bash",
  "args": [
    "-lc",
    "SYMBOL=\"${ZED_SELECTED_TEXT:-}\"; [ -z \"$SYMBOL\" ] && exit 0; open \"https://docs.supercollider.online/Classes/$SYMBOL\""
  ],
  "reveal": "never",
  "hide": "on_success"
}
```

## Open questions
- How to determine if selection is a class vs method vs guide?
- Fallback to search if exact match not found?
- Should we validate the symbol exists first (via quark) before opening?
close_reason: Prototype complete. All learnings consolidated in .ai/research/help-docs-feature.md. Real solution tracked in 52i (hover integration).

title: Distribution & Installability
description: Installable extension without repo checkout. Deterministic launcher/quark discovery (Quarks install required for users; vendored quark for dev), global tasks.json guidance, clean metadata, user-facing INSTALL + troubleshooting, release smoke.
design:
## Plan

### Extension Packaging
- Keep extension self-contained: grammar wasm, queries, snippets, runnables.
- Tasks live in user global `~/.config/zed/tasks.json`; no per-project `.zed`.

### Launcher Distribution
- Primary channel: cargo install; secondary: GitHub release binaries.
- Discovery: settings.path > PATH > dev fallback (repo-only). Add --mode probe health check + slash-command help.

### LanguageServer.quark Strategy
- Require Quarks.install("LanguageServer") for distribution; keep vendored quark for dev only.

### Tasks/Runnables UX
- Runnables map to tasks in user global config; expose eval/boot/stop keypaths; single Post Window task tied to SC_TMP_DIR/TMPDIR.

### Documentation
- INSTALL.md: prerequisites (SC app, Quarks install), global tasks.json snippet, launcher install, settings snippet, troubleshoot.
- DEV.md: hacking on repo, vendored quark, dev launcher fallback.

### Release/Verification
- Smoke: launcher probe, LSP init, HTTP eval 202, tasks work with global config, extension bundle clean of dev artifacts.

## Open Decisions
1. Cargo install UX vs release binaries: finalize install string + platform coverage.
2. Versioning/publish cadence for extension + launcher and how to surface in docs.
notes:
## Principles
- Keep extension self-contained (grammar wasm, queries, snippets/keymaps, runnables) with no per-project .zed dependence.
- Tasks are user-global (tasks.json) and documented; no hidden per-project requirements.
- Treat launcher + quark as external deps discoverable via PATH or settings; preserve dev ergonomics without leaking dev defaults.
- Prefer deterministic discovery and actionable logging over heuristics.

title: Orphaned sclang processes: multiple instances spawning
description:
## Problem
User observed 4 sclang processes running simultaneously when only 1 should exist. This indicates process management is unreliable under unknown conditions.

## Symptoms
- Multiple sclang processes spawned
- Processes not being cleaned up properly
- Occurs 'when not looking' (possibly during editor restart, recompile, or crash recovery)

## Investigation needed
1. Check PID file handling - is it being checked/cleaned up properly?
2. Check what happens when:
   - Zed restarts rapidly
   - sclang crashes vs exits gracefully
   - Extension is disabled/enabled
   - Recompile triggers
3. Review graceful_shutdown_child() for edge cases
4. Check if IS_RUNNING guard is working correctly
5. Look for race conditions in spawn/shutdown sequence

## Related
- m78.2 (just completed) improved shutdown handling but may not cover all cases
- PID file at $TMPDIR/sc_launcher.pid should prevent duplicate spawns

## Reproduction
Unknown - need to identify trigger conditions
close_reason: Added cleanup_orphaned_processes() that runs at startup to: (1) check PID file for dead launchers and kill their orphaned sclang, (2) scan for any sclang with PPID=1 and kill them

title: Address LSP provider performance and robustness issues
description:
Code review of commits 8994fa3-5bf2834 identified several issues:

HIGH PRIORITY:
- Performance: Synchronous file I/O in HoverProvider.sc:56 and FindReferencesProvider.prClassDocRange:98 blocks on disk. Add caching layer for class documentation.
- Race condition: TextDocumentProvider didChange handler forces isOpen=true without proper initialization (commit 3525618). Need proper document initialization or change queueing.

MEDIUM PRIORITY:
- Fragile comment extraction: HoverProvider and FindReferencesProvider use simple find() to extract class docs, can match wrong comments. Should parse from class definition location.
- Code duplication: Rehydration pattern duplicated across HoverProvider, FindReferencesProvider, DocumentSymbolProvider. Extract to LSPDocument.ensureHydrated() helper.

Recommendations:
1. Add LSPDatabase.getClassDocumentation() with classDocCache
2. Extract rehydration to LSPDocument.ensureHydrated(uri)
3. Improve comment extraction to search from class charPos
4. Add tests for race conditions and edge cases

Files: HoverProvider.sc, FindReferencesProvider.sc, DocumentSymbolProvider.sc, TextDocumentProvider.sc, LSPDatabase.sc
close_reason: Fixed HIGH priority items: added class doc caching in LSPDatabase (getFileContent, getClassDocumentation, getClassDocRange), updated HoverProvider and FindReferencesProvider to use cache, fixed didChange race condition with proper rehydration

title: Quark identity: rename and publish forked LanguageServer
description:
We maintain a modified fork of LanguageServer.quark with Zed-specific changes. Users cannot use the upstream quark. This creates confusion and installation friction.

## Problem
- Our quark is in server/quark/LanguageServer.quark but is NOT the upstream LanguageServer
- Users who Quarks.install('LanguageServer') get the wrong one
- README doesn't clarify this
- Launcher has workarounds (--include-path, --exclude-path) to prefer vendored copy

## Proposed Solution
1. **Rename quark** to distinguish from upstream (e.g., ZedLanguageServer, zed-supercollider-lsp)
2. **Publish to Quarks registry** under new name so users can Quarks.install it
3. **Update launcher** to reference new quark name in logs/errors
4. **Update README** with clear install instructions
5. **Update AGENTS.md** anti-patterns section

## Scope
- server/quark/LanguageServer.quark/ (rename directory + internal references)
- server/launcher/src/main.rs (quark detection, logging)
- README.md, INSTALL.md
- Quarks registry submission

## Open Questions
- What name? ZedLanguageServer vs zed-supercollider-lsp vs other
- Should upstream LanguageServer be listed as a conflict/alternative?
- Do we need to coordinate with upstream maintainer?

title: Distribution strategy: research and decision
description:
Comprehensive research on distribution strategy for zed-supercollider. Goal: make the extension installable for non-professional programmers (students, artists) with minimal friction, as close to the default SuperCollider IDE experience as possible.

## Target Audience
- Students learning SuperCollider
- Artists/musicians who aren't professional programmers
- Users who expect "download and it works" experience
- Users who may not have Rust toolchain, Homebrew, or terminal comfort

## Research Findings

### Zed Extension Capabilities

**What extensions CAN do:**
- Auto-download binaries at runtime via GitHub releases (how rust-analyzer, pyright work)
- Use `download_file()`, `get_github_release()`, `make_file_executable()` APIs
- Write to workspace directories (project-local .zed/)
- Define slash commands
- Define runnables via runnables.scm

**What extensions CANNOT do:**
- Bundle native binaries in the extension itself (WASM sandbox)
- Write to user config (~/.config/zed/tasks.json, settings.json)
- Run post-install scripts
- Automatically install SuperCollider Quarks

**Discovery order for language servers:**
1. User-configured path (lsp.{server}.binary.path in settings)
2. System PATH search
3. Automatic download from GitHub releases

### SuperCollider Ecosystem Patterns

**Official SC IDE:**
- Batteries-included: download one installer, everything works
- Bundles scsynth, sclang, scide, docs, Quarks manager
- Students expect this level of polish

**VS Code SC Extension:**
- Requires separate SC app install
- Requires manual sclang path configuration in settings
- Some extensions require manual Quarks.install("LanguageServer")
- Not a great UX benchmark

**Quarks for end users:**
- GUI available via Quarks.gui (user-friendly)
- Must recompile class library after install
- Our fork conflicts with upstream LanguageServer name

### Current Component State

**Launcher (sc_launcher):**
- Rust binary, ~1.8 MB release build
- Bridges LSP stdio↔UDP between Zed and LanguageServer.quark
- HTTP server for code eval (port 57130)
- Already has vendored quark discovery logic

**LanguageServer.quark:**
- ~288 KB (50 files)
- Forked from upstream with critical fixes
- Vendored as submodule at server/quark/LanguageServer.quark/
- Cannot use upstream—our fork has fixes for crashes, timing, logging

**Extension:**
- Grammar WASM, queries, snippets, runnables
- ~24 KB language assets
- Currently requires manual launcher path config

---

## Distribution Approaches

### Approach A: Auto-Download Bundle (RECOMMENDED)

**User experience:**
1. User installs extension from Zed marketplace (one click)
2. User opens a .sc file
3. Extension auto-downloads from GitHub releases:
   - Platform-specific tarball (darwin-arm64, darwin-x64, linux-x64, windows-x64)
   - Contains: sc_launcher binary + LanguageServer.quark folder
4. Extracts to ~/.local/share/zed/languages/supercollider/
5. LSP starts working immediately

**What we'd build:**
- GitHub Actions workflow for multi-platform release builds
- Tarball packaging with launcher + quark bundled
- Extension code: platform detection, download, extract, set executable
- Version checking for auto-updates

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) No toolchain required (no cargo, no brew)
- (+) Cross-platform with single approach
- (+) Closest to "just works"
- (-) Windows code signing ($300+/year) or "untrusted publisher" warning
- (-) macOS may need notarization ($99/year) or users right-click → Open
- (-) Quark updates require new launcher release

**Uninstall:** Delete extension. Downloaded files stay in ~/.local/share/zed/languages/

### Approach B: Installer Script

**User experience:**
```bash
# macOS/Linux
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/.../install.sh | bash

# Windows PowerShell
irm https://raw.githubusercontent.com/.../install.ps1 | iex
```

**Script actions:**
1. Detect OS and architecture
2. Download latest release tarball
3. Extract to ~/.local/bin/sc_launcher
4. Copy quark to ~/.local/share/SuperCollider/Extensions/
5. Optionally write tasks to ~/.config/zed/tasks.json
6. Print completion message

**What we'd build:**
- install.sh with platform detection
- install.ps1 for Windows
- uninstall.sh / uninstall.ps1
- Same GitHub Actions releases as Approach A

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Can automate tasks.json setup
- (+) Familiar pattern for developers
- (+) Explicit user control
- (-) Requires terminal comfort
- (-) curl|bash controversial (security concerns)
- (-) Students may not know how to open Terminal

### Approach C: Native Platform Installers

**macOS (.pkg):**
- Standard installer wizard
- Installs to /usr/local/bin/ and /Library/Application Support/SuperCollider/Extensions/
- Post-install script could write tasks.json

**Windows (.msi):**
- Standard installer wizard
- Installs to C:\Program Files\SuperCollider-Zed\
- Adds to PATH automatically

**Linux (.deb/.rpm/AppImage):**
- Package manager or standalone AppImage

**What we'd build:**
- macOS: pkgbuild/productbuild scripts
- Windows: WiX or Inno Setup
- Linux: debian packaging, RPM spec, AppImage recipe
- Code signing certificates

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Best native UX per platform
- (+) Standard uninstall mechanisms
- (-) Significant packaging work per platform
- (-) Code signing costs ($99-$300+/year)
- (-) Maintenance burden for updates

---

## Tasks.json Solutions

Core problem: Zed extensions cannot write to user config (~/.config/zed/tasks.json). But we need tasks for Eval/Boot/Stop/Post Window.

### Idea 1: Auto-Generate Per-Project .zed/tasks.json (RECOMMENDED)

**How it works:**
- Extension detects folder with .sc files
- If no .zed/tasks.json exists, extension creates it automatically
- Treats .zed/ like .vscode/ - editor config in project

**Feasibility:** Extensions CAN write to workspace directory. This should work.

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Zero config, invisible to user
- (+) Every SC project gets tasks automatically
- (-) Creates files in user's project
- (-) Some users dislike auto-generated files
- Mitigation: Add .zed/ to common .gitignore patterns

### Idea 2: Runnables as Primary Interface

**How it works:**
- Runnables already detect (...) blocks via runnables.scm
- User clicks ▶ button next to code blocks
- Could offer Eval/Boot/Stop options

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Very discoverable (buttons in editor)
- (+) No config needed
- (-) Need to verify runnables can replace tasks fully
- (-) May still need tasks for Boot/Stop server

### Idea 3: Slash Commands for Everything

**How it works:**
- /sc-eval, /sc-boot, /sc-stop, /sc-post commands
- Hit HTTP API directly from extension

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Works everywhere, no tasks.json needed
- (+) User learns once
- (-) Less discoverable than task runner
- (-) No keyboard shortcuts by default

### Idea 4: First-Run Setup Wizard

**How it works:**
- /sc-setup slash command
- Checks prerequisites, prints status
- Offers to create .zed/tasks.json in current project
- Copies config to clipboard for global tasks.json

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Guided setup, user feels in control
- (+) Teaches user about the system
- (-) Extra step after install

### Idea 5: Opinionated Default (variant of Idea 1)

**How it works:**
- Extension ALWAYS creates .zed/tasks.json when opening SC files
- Document clearly: "Extension manages .zed/tasks.json"
- If user deletes it, recreate on next open

**Tradeoffs:**
- (+) Zero config
- (-) Some users will complain

---

## Recommendations

**Distribution:** Approach A (auto-download bundle) as primary, with Approach B (installer script) documented for power users who prefer explicit control.

**Tasks:** Idea 1 (auto-generate .zed/tasks.json per project) combined with Idea 4 (setup wizard /sc-setup) for discoverability and troubleshooting.

**Quark:** Bundle with launcher in release tarball. Launcher already has vendored quark discovery logic.

---

## Comparison to VS Code SC Extension

| Step | VS Code | Zed (proposed) |
|------|---------|----------------|
| Install SC app | Manual | Manual |
| Install extension | Marketplace | Marketplace |
| Configure sclang path | Manual settings | Auto-detected |
| Install quark | Manual Quarks.install | Bundled (auto) |
| Configure tasks | N/A | Auto-generated |

We would be BETTER than VS Code on quark handling and tasks if we implement this.

---

## Open Questions

1. Code signing: Is $99-$300/year acceptable for notarization/signing?
2. Auto-update: How aggressive should version checking be?
3. .zed/ gitignore: Should we advocate adding .zed/ to .gitignore templates?
4. Quark naming: Still need to rename fork before publishing (see zed-supercollider-c9o)

---

## Related Issues

- zed-supercollider-75x: Distribution & Installability (parent epic)
- zed-supercollider-c9o: Quark identity rename (blocks this)

title: ZED_SELECTED_TEXT broken with vim mode
description:
## Issue
ZED_SELECTED_TEXT environment variable is not populated when Zed's vim mode is enabled. Works fine with vim mode disabled.

## Findings
- ZED_ROW, ZED_FILE, ZED_COLUMN all work fine

title: References crash fix
description:
## Fix Applied
Changed line 61 from:
```supercollider
var includeDecl = params["context"] !? _["includeDeclaration"] !? _.asBoolean ?? { false };
```
to:
```supercollider
var includeDecl = (params["context"] !? _["includeDeclaration"]) == true;
```

**Root cause:** The JSON parser returns strings ("true") not booleans, and SuperCollider's String class lacks `.asBoolean`. The original code also had this bug but wasn't triggered until includeDeclaration was actually sent.

**Fix:** Direct equality check against boolean `true`. Safe default (false) for nil/string/other values.

title: Prototype: Help docs via schelp→markdown converter
description:
Prototype approach for viewing SuperCollider help docs in Zed using markdown preview.

## Current Status
Raw schelp viewer working on `prototype/help-browser` branch via `less` pager.

## Two rendering approaches to try

### Approach A: sclang HTML renderer + terminal browser
1. Use sclang's `SCDoc.prepareHelpForURL` to render schelp→HTML
2. Use terminal HTML browser (lynx, w3m, elinks) to render in terminal
3. Display in Zed's terminal panel

### Approach B: Custom scdoc→markdown converter
1. Read the scdoc spec/source to understand format
2. Write converter (in SC or Rust)
3. Output markdown, open in Zed's markdown preview

## scdoc format reference (from SinOsc.schelp)
```
class:: ClassName
summary:: Short description
related:: Classes/Foo, Classes/Bar
categories:: Category>Subcategory

Description::
Paragraph text with code::inline code:: and link::Classes/Foo::.

classmethods::
method::methodName
argument::argName
Description of argument.

Examples::
code::
{ SinOsc.ar(440) }.play;
::
```

## Key mappings
- `class::` → `# ClassName`
- `summary::` → italic or subtitle
- `code::...::` → `\`...\`` (inline) or fenced block
- `link::Classes/Foo::` → `[Foo](url)`
- `method::` → `## methodName`
- `argument::` → `**argName**`
- `Description::`, `Examples::` → `## Description`, `## Examples`
- `LIST:: ## item ::` → `- item`
- `note::...::` → blockquote

## Research findings
(see previous research in issue history)
close_reason: Phase 1 complete: Pandoc Lua reader implemented in tools/schelp/schelp.lua. Converts schelp to markdown with support for headers, sections, methods, arguments, code blocks, links, and lists. Phase 2 (Zed hover integration) tracked in zed-supercollider-52i.
